title: Rolling - Different shapes roll down ramp

content.question: A hollow sphere, a uniform solid sphere, and a hoop are placed at the top of a ramp of length <math alttext="L" display="inline" overflow="scroll"><mi>L</mi></math> that makes an angle <math alttext="theta" display="inline" overflow="scroll"><mi>θ</mi></math> with the horizontal, as shown in the figure. The hollow sphere, solid sphere, and hoop have the same mass <math alttext="M" display="inline" overflow="scroll"><mi>M</mi></math> and the same radius <math alttext="R" display="inline" overflow="scroll"><mi>R</mi></math>. All three shapes are released from rest at the same time and roll down the ramp without slipping. (a) Rank the order in which the shapes reach the bottom of the ramp. A ranking of “<math alttext="1" display="inline" overflow="scroll"><mn>1</mn></math>” indicates the shape reaches the bottom of the ramp first. If any two shapes reach the bottom of the ramp at the same time, give them the same ranking._____Hollow Sphere _____Uniform Solid Sphere _____HoopJustify your rankings using relevant physics principles, but without directly manipulating or deriving equations.

A new sphere is constructed using a thin spherical shell of radius <math alttext="R" display="inline" overflow="scroll"><mi>R</mi></math>. The shell is completely filled with liquid. The mass of the shell is much less than that of the liquid, and the total mass of the liquid-filled sphere is <math alttext="M" display="inline" overflow="scroll"><mi>M</mi></math>. The liquid-filled sphere is placed at the top of the ramp, released from rest, and rolls without slipping to the bottom of the ramp. As the sphere rolls down the ramp, the liquid inside the sphere does not rotate with the shell.(c) Does the liquid-filled sphere reach the bottom of the ramp in more time, less time, or the same time as the solid sphere? Use the equation derived in part (b) to justify your answer.
